Literature Review: The organic anion transporters (OATs), organic anion transporting polypeptides (OATPs), and multidrug resistance proteins (MRPs) play crucial roles in the movement of various organic anions across cellular membranes. These transporters, belonging to the SLC22, SLCO, and ABCC families respectively, are integral to maintaining homeostasis and facilitating interorgan and interorganismal communication. This literature review explores the current understanding of these transporters in the context of the remote sensing and signaling theory, focusing on their roles in endogenous metabolism and disease states.OATs, particularly OAT1 (SLC22A6) and OAT3 (SLC22A8), are primarily expressed in the kidneys and have been extensively studied for their role in drug disposition and elimination. However, recent research has highlighted their importance in endogenous metabolite handling. Nigam et al. (2015) proposed that OAT1 and OAT3 function as 'metabolite sensors,' regulating the plasma and tissue levels of various small molecules involved in metabolism and signaling. This concept aligns with the remote sensing and signaling theory, which posits that transporters and metabolizing enzymes work in concert to maintain optimal levels of endogenous substrates throughout the body.OATPs, including OATP1B1 (SLCO1B1) and OATP1B3 (SLCO1B3), are predominantly expressed in the liver and play a crucial role in the hepatic uptake of various compounds. Hagenbuch and Stieger (2013) reviewed the substrate specificity of these transporters, highlighting their importance in bile acid homeostasis and drug disposition. The broad substrate specificity of OATPs allows them to mediate the transport of numerous endogenous and exogenous organic anions, contributing to their role in interorgan communication.MRPs, such as MRP2 (ABCC2) and MRP4 (ABCC4), are ATP-dependent efflux transporters that play essential roles in cellular detoxification and signaling molecule export. Keppler (2011) provided an extensive review of the physiological functions of MRP2, emphasizing its role in the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various other organic anions. MRP4, on the other hand, has been shown to transport a wide range of signaling molecules, including cyclic nucleotides and prostaglandins, suggesting a role in cell-to-cell communication.The remote sensing and signaling theory, as proposed by Ahn and Nigam (2009), provides a framework for understanding how these transporters contribute to the maintenance of systemic homeostasis. This theory suggests that transporters and metabolizing enzymes form a network that senses and regulates the levels of various metabolites and signaling molecules across different organs and even between organisms.Recent studies have provided evidence supporting this theory. For instance, Eraly et al. (2018) demonstrated that OAT1 knockout mice exhibit altered metabolic profiles, suggesting a role for this transporter in regulating systemic metabolism. Similarly, Stieger and Hagenbuch (2014) reviewed the role of OATPs in bile acid homeostasis, highlighting how these transporters contribute to the enterohepatic circulation of bile acids and, consequently, to whole-body cholesterol homeostasis.The interplay between these transporters and the gut microbiome has also gained attention in recent years. Uchida et al. (2015) showed that the expression of certain OATs and OATPs is altered in germ-free mice, suggesting a link between the gut microbiota and transporter function. This finding supports the concept of interorganismal communication proposed in the remote sensing and signaling theory.In disease states, the coordinated function of these transporters can be disrupted, leading to various pathological conditions. For example, Srimaroeng et al. (2015) reviewed the role of OATs in chronic kidney disease, highlighting how the accumulation of uremic toxins due to impaired OAT function can contribute to disease progression. Similarly, Kalliokoski and Niemi (2009) discussed how polymorphisms in OATP genes can affect drug disposition and efficacy, emphasizing the clinical relevance of these transporters.The breast cancer resistance protein (BCRP, ABCG2) is another important transporter that, while not part of the OAT, OATP, or MRP families, plays a significant role in the transport of various endogenous and exogenous compounds. Mao and Unadkat (2015) reviewed the physiological role of BCRP, highlighting its importance in urate transport and its potential involvement in gout pathogenesis.In conclusion, the OAT, OATP, and MRP transporters form a complex network that regulates the movement of various organic anions between tissues and body fluids. The remote sensing and signaling theory provides a framework for understanding how these transporters contribute to systemic homeostasis and interorgan communication. Future research in this field will likely focus on elucidating the precise mechanisms by which these transporters sense and respond to changes in metabolite levels, as well as exploring their potential as therapeutic targets in various diseases.
